pseudoClasses.description: Windows Store apps only. Applies one or more styles to an element when it has focus and the user presses the space bar.

pseudoClasses.name: :-ms-lang
pseudoClasses.description: Represents an element that is in the language specified. Accepts a comma separated list of language tokens.

pseudoClasses.name: :no-button
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Applies to track pieces. Applies when there is no button at that end of the track.

pseudoClasses.name: :not
pseudoClasses.description: The negation pseudo-class, :not(X), is a functional notation taking a simple selector (excluding the negation pseudo-class itself) as an argument. It represents an element that is not represented by its argument.

pseudoClasses.name: :nth-child
pseudoClasses.description: Represents an element that has an+b-1 siblings before it in the document tree, for any positive integer or zero value of n, and has a parent element.

pseudoClasses.name: :nth-last-child
pseudoClasses.description: Represents an element that has an+b-1 siblings after it in the document tree, for any positive integer or zero value of n, and has a parent element.

pseudoClasses.name: :nth-last-of-type
pseudoClasses.description: Represents an element that has an+b-1 siblings with the same expanded element name after it in the document tree, for any zero or positive integer value of n, and has a parent element.

pseudoClasses.name: :nth-of-type
pseudoClasses.description: Represents an element that has an+b-1 siblings with the same expanded element name before it in the document tree, for any zero or positive integer value of n, and has a parent element.

pseudoClasses.name: :only-child
pseudoClasses.description: Represents an element that has a parent element and whose parent element has no other element children. Same as :first-child:last-child or :nth-child(1):nth-last-child(1), but with a lower specificity.

pseudoClasses.name: :only-of-type
pseudoClasses.description: Matches every element that is the only child of its type, of its parent. Same as :first-of-type:last-of-type or :nth-of-type(1):nth-last-of-type(1), but with a lower specificity.

pseudoClasses.name: :optional
pseudoClasses.description: A form element is :required or :optional if a value for it is, respectively, required or optional before the form it belongs to is submitted. Elements that are not form elements are neither required nor optional.

pseudoClasses.name: :out-of-range
pseudoClasses.description: Used in conjunction with the min and max attributes, whether on a range input, a number field, or any other types that accept those attributes.

pseudoClasses.name: :past
pseudoClasses.description: Represents any element that is defined to occur entirely prior to a :current element.

pseudoClasses.name: :read-only
pseudoClasses.description: An element whose contents are not user-alterable is :read-only. However, elements whose contents are user-alterable (such as text input fields) are considered to be in a :read-write state. In typical documents, most elements are :read-only.

pseudoClasses.name: :read-write
pseudoClasses.description: An element whose contents are not user-alterable is :read-only. However, elements whose contents are user-alterable (such as text input fields) are considered to be in a :read-write state. In typical documents, most elements are :read-only.

pseudoClasses.name: :required
pseudoClasses.description: A form element is :required or :optional if a value for it is, respectively, required or optional before the form it belongs to is submitted. Elements that are not form elements are neither required nor optional.

pseudoClasses.name: :right
pseudoClasses.description: When printing double-sided documents, the page boxes on left and right pages may be different. This can be expressed through CSS pseudo-classes defined in the  page context.

pseudoClasses.name: :root
pseudoClasses.description: Represents an element that is the root of the document. In HTML 4, this is always the HTML element.

pseudoClasses.name: :scope
pseudoClasses.description: Represents any element that is in the contextual reference element set.

pseudoClasses.name: :single-button
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Applies to buttons and track pieces. Applies when both buttons are displayed separately at either end of the scrollbar.

pseudoClasses.name: :start
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Applies to buttons and track pieces. Indicates whether the object is placed before the thumb.

pseudoClasses.name: :target
pseudoClasses.description: Some URIs refer to a location within a resource. This kind of URI ends with a 'number sign' (#) followed by an anchor identifier (called the fragment identifier).

pseudoClasses.name: :valid
pseudoClasses.description: An element is :valid or :invalid when it is, respectively, valid or invalid with respect to data validity semantics defined by a different specification.

pseudoClasses.name: :vertical
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Applies to any scrollbar pieces that have a vertical orientation.

pseudoClasses.name: :visited
pseudoClasses.description: Applies once the link has been visited by the user.

pseudoClasses.name: :-webkit-any
pseudoClasses.description: Represents an element that is represented by the selector list passed as its argument. Standardized as :matches().

pseudoClasses.name: :-webkit-full-screen
pseudoClasses.description: Matches any element that has its fullscreen flag set. Standardized as :fullscreen.

pseudoClasses.name: :window-inactive
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Applies to all scrollbar pieces. Indicates whether or not the window containing the scrollbar is currently active.

pseudoClasses.name: :autofill
pseudoClasses.description: The :autofill CSS pseudo-class matches when an input element has its value autofilled by the browser. The class stops matching if the user edits the field.

pseudoClasses.name: :blank
pseudoClasses.description: The :blank CSS pseudo-class selects empty user input elements (eg. <input> or <textarea>).

pseudoClasses.name: :buffering
pseudoClasses.description: The :buffering CSS pseudo-class selector represents an element that is playable, such as audio or video, when the playable element is buffering a media resource.

pseudoClasses.name: :current
pseudoClasses.description: The :current CSS pseudo-class selector is a time-dimensional pseudo-class that represents the element, or an ancestor of the element, that is currently being displayed

pseudoClasses.name: :defined
pseudoClasses.description: The :defined CSS pseudo-class represents any element that has been defined. This includes any standard element built in to the browser, and custom elements that have been successfully defined (i.e. with the CustomElementRegistry.define() method).

pseudoClasses.name: :dir
pseudoClasses.description: The :dir() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on the directionality of the text contained in them.

pseudoClasses.name: :focus-visible
pseudoClasses.description: The :focus-visible pseudo-class applies while an element matches the :focus pseudo-class and the UA determines via heuristics that the focus should be made evident on the element.

pseudoClasses.name: :focus-within
pseudoClasses.description: The :focus-within pseudo-class applies to any element for which the :focus pseudo class applies as well as to an element whose descendant in the flat tree (including non-element nodes, such as text nodes) matches the conditions for matching :focus.

pseudoClasses.name: :has
pseudoClasses.description: The functional :has() CSS pseudo-class represents an element if any of the relative selectors that are passed as an argument match at least one element when anchored against this element.

pseudoClasses.name: :has-slotted
pseudoClasses.description: The :has-slotted CSS pseudo-class matches when the content of a slot element is not empty or not using the default value (see Using templates and slots for more information).

pseudoClasses.name: :is
pseudoClasses.description: The :is() CSS pseudo-class function takes a selector list as its argument, and selects any element that can be selected by one of the selectors in that list. This is useful for writing large selectors in a more compact form.

pseudoClasses.name: :local-link
pseudoClasses.description: The :local-link CSS pseudo-class represents an link to the same document

pseudoClasses.name: :modal
pseudoClasses.description: The :modal CSS pseudo-class matches an element that is in a state in which it excludes all interaction with elements outside it until the interaction has been dismissed. Multiple elements can be selected by the :modal pseudo-class at the same time, but only one of them will be active and able to receive input.

pseudoClasses.name: :muted
pseudoClasses.description: The :muted CSS pseudo-class selector represents an element that is capable of making sound, such as audio or video, but is muted (forced silent).

pseudoClasses.name: :open
pseudoClasses.description: The :open CSS pseudo-class represents an element that has open and closed states, only when it is currently in the open state.

pseudoClasses.name: :paused
pseudoClasses.description: The :paused CSS pseudo-class selector is a resource state pseudo-class that will match an audio, video, or similar resource that is capable of being â€œplayedâ€ or â€œpausedâ€, when that element is â€œpausedâ€.

pseudoClasses.name: :picture-in-picture
pseudoClasses.description: The :picture-in-picture CSS pseudo-class matches the element which is currently in picture-in-picture mode.

pseudoClasses.name: :placeholder-shown
pseudoClasses.description: The :placeholder-shown CSS pseudo-class represents any <input> or <textarea> element that is currently displaying placeholder text.

pseudoClasses.name: :playing
pseudoClasses.description: The :playing CSS pseudo-class selector is a resource state pseudo-class that will match an audio, video, or similar resource that is capable of being â€œplayedâ€ or â€œpausedâ€, when that element is â€œplayingâ€.

pseudoClasses.name: :popover-open
pseudoClasses.description: The :popover-open CSS pseudo-class represents a {{domxref("Popover API", "popover", "", "nocode")}} element (i.e. one with a popover attribute) that is in the showing state. You can use this to apply style to popover elements only when they are shown.

pseudoClasses.name: :seeking
pseudoClasses.description: The :seeking CSS pseudo-class selector represents an element that is playable, such as audio or video, when the playable element is seeking a playback position in the media resource.

pseudoClasses.name: :stalled
pseudoClasses.description: The :stalled CSS pseudo-class selector represents an element that is playable, such as audio or video, when playback is stalled.

pseudoClasses.name: :state
pseudoClasses.description: The :state() CSS pseudo-class matches custom elements that have the specified custom state.

pseudoClasses.name: :target-current
pseudoClasses.description: The :target-current CSS pseudo-class selects the active scroll marker â€” the ::scroll-marker pseudo-element of a scroll-marker-group that is currently scrolled to. This selector can be used to style the active navigation position within a scroll marker group.

pseudoClasses.name: :target-within
pseudoClasses.description: The :target-within CSS pseudo-class represents an element that is a target element or contains an element that is a target. A target element is a unique element with an id matching the URL's fragment.

pseudoClasses.name: :user-invalid
pseudoClasses.description: The :user-invalid CSS pseudo-class represents any validated form element whose value isn't valid based on their validation constraints, after the user has interacted with it.

pseudoClasses.name: :user-valid
pseudoClasses.description: The :user-valid CSS pseudo-class represents any validated form element whose value validates correctly based on its validation constraints. However, unlike :valid it only matches once the user has interacted with it.

pseudoClasses.name: :volume-locked
pseudoClasses.description: The :volume-locked CSS pseudo-class selector represents an element that is capable of making sound, such as audio or video, but the audio volume of the media element is currently "locked" by the user.

pseudoClasses.name: :where
pseudoClasses.description: The :where() CSS pseudo-class function takes a selector list as its argument, and selects any element that can be selected by one of the selectors in that list.

pseudoElements.name: ::after
pseudoElements.description: Represents a styleable child pseudo-element immediately after the originating element's actual content.

pseudoElements.name: ::backdrop
pseudoElements.description: Used to create a backdrop that hides the underlying document for an element in a top layer (such as an element that is displayed fullscreen).

pseudoElements.name: ::before
pseudoElements.description: Represents a styleable child pseudo-element immediately before the originating element's actual content.

pseudoElements.name: ::content
pseudoElements.description: Deprecated. Matches the distribution list itself, on elements that have one. Use ::slotted for forward compatibility.

pseudoElements.name: ::first-letter
pseudoElements.description: Represents the first letter of an element, if it is not preceded by any other content (such as images or inline tables) on its line.

pseudoElements.name: ::first-line
pseudoElements.description: Describes the contents of the first formatted line of its originating element.

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-list-bullet
pseudoElements.description: Used to style the bullet of a list element. Similar to the standardized ::marker.

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-list-number
pseudoElements.description: Used to style the numbers of a list element. Similar to the standardized ::marker.

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-placeholder
pseudoElements.description: Represents placeholder text in an input field

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-progress-bar
pseudoElements.description: Represents the bar portion of a progress bar.

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-selection
pseudoElements.description: Represents the portion of a document that has been highlighted by the user.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-backdrop
pseudoElements.description: Used to create a backdrop that hides the underlying document for an element in a top layer (such as an element that is displayed fullscreen).

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-browse
pseudoElements.description: Represents the browse button of an input type=file control.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-check
pseudoElements.description: Represents the check of a checkbox or radio button input control.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-clear
pseudoElements.description: Represents the clear button of a text input control

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-expand
pseudoElements.description: Represents the drop-down button of a select control.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-fill
pseudoElements.description: Represents the bar portion of a progress bar.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-fill-lower
pseudoElements.description: Represents the portion of the slider track from its smallest value up to the value currently selected by the thumb. In a left-to-right layout, this is the portion of the slider track to the left of the thumb.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-fill-upper
pseudoElements.description: Represents the portion of the slider track from the value currently selected by the thumb up to the slider's largest value. In a left-to-right layout, this is the portion of the slider track to the right of the thumb.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-reveal
pseudoElements.description: Represents the password reveal button of an input type=password control.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-thumb
pseudoElements.description: Represents the portion of range input control (also known as a slider control) that the user drags.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-ticks-after
pseudoElements.description: Represents the tick marks of a slider that begin just after the thumb and continue up to the slider's largest value. In a left-to-right layout, these are the ticks to the right of the thumb.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-ticks-before
pseudoElements.description: Represents the tick marks of a slider that represent its smallest values up to the value currently selected by the thumb. In a left-to-right layout, these are the ticks to the left of the thumb.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-tooltip
pseudoElements.description: Represents the tooltip of a slider (input type=range).

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-track
pseudoElements.description: Represents the track of a slider.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-value
pseudoElements.description: Represents the content of a text or password input control, or a select control.

pseudoElements.name: ::selection
pseudoElements.description: Represents the portion of a document that has been highlighted by the user.

pseudoElements.name: ::shadow
pseudoElements.description: Matches the shadow root if an element has a shadow tree.

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-range-progress
pseudoElements.description: The ::-moz-range-progress CSS pseudo-element is a Mozilla extension that represents the lower portion of the track (i.e., groove) in which the indicator slides in an <input> of type="range". This portion corresponds to values lower than the value currently selected by the thumb (i.e., virtual knob).

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-range-thumb
pseudoElements.description: The ::-moz-range-thumb CSS pseudo-element is a Mozilla extension that represents the thumb (i.e., virtual knob) of an <input> of type="range". The user can move the thumb along the input's track to alter its numerical value.

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-range-track
pseudoElements.description: The ::-moz-range-track CSS pseudo-element is a Mozilla extension that represents the track (i.e., groove) in which the indicator slides in an <input> of type="range".

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-progress-inner-value
pseudoElements.description:
The ::-webkit-progress-value CSS pseudo-element represents the filled-in portion of the bar of a <progress> element. It is a child of the ::-webkit-progress-bar pseudo-element.

In order to let ::-webkit-progress-value take effect, -webkit-appearance needs to be set to none on the <progress> element.

pseudoElements.name: ::checkmark
pseudoElements.description: The ::checkmark CSS pseudo-element targets the checkmark placed inside the currently-selected option element of a customizable select element. It can be used to provide a visual indication of which option is selected.

pseudoElements.name: ::details-content
pseudoElements.description: The ::details-content CSS pseudo-element represents the expandable/collapsible contents of a details element.

pseudoElements.name: ::file-selector-button
pseudoElements.description: The ::file-selector-button CSS pseudo-element represents the button of an input of type="file".

pseudoElements.name: ::grammar-error
pseudoElements.description: The ::grammar-error CSS pseudo-element represents a text segment which the user agent has flagged as grammatically incorrect.

pseudoElements.name: ::highlight
pseudoElements.description: The ::highlight() CSS pseudo-element applies styles to a custom highlight.

pseudoElements.name: ::marker
pseudoElements.description: The ::marker CSS pseudo-element selects the marker box of a list item, which typically contains a bullet or number. It works on any element or pseudo-element set to display: list-item, such as the <li> and <summary> elements.

pseudoElements.name: ::part
pseudoElements.description: The ::part CSS pseudo-element represents any element within a shadow tree that has a matching part attribute.

pseudoElements.name: ::picker-icon
pseudoElements.description: The ::picker-icon CSS pseudo-element targets the picker icon inside form controls that have an icon associated with them. In the case of a customizable select element, it selects the arrow icon shown on the <select> element that points down when it is closed.

pseudoElements.name: ::placeholder
pseudoElements.description: The ::placeholder CSS pseudo-element represents the placeholder text of a form element.

pseudoElements.name: ::scroll-marker
pseudoElements.description: The ::scroll-marker CSS pseudo-element can be generated inside any element and represents its scroll marker. All elements can have a ::scroll-marker pseudo-element, which is placed into the ::scroll-marker-group of the nearest scroll container ancestor. A scroll marker behaves like an anchor (a element) whose scroll target is the marker's originating element â€” and scrolls the scroll container to that element when activated.

pseudoElements.name: ::scroll-marker-group
pseudoElements.description: The ::scroll-marker-group CSS pseudo-element is generated inside a scroll container and contains any ::scroll-marker pseudo-elements generated on descendants of the scroll container.

pseudoElements.name: ::slotted
pseudoElements.description: The ::slotted() CSS pseudo-element represents any element that has been placed into a slot inside an HTML template (see Using templates and slots for more information).

pseudoElements.name: ::spelling-error
pseudoElements.description: The ::spelling-error CSS pseudo-element represents a text segment which the user agent has flagged as incorrectly spelled.

pseudoElements.name: ::target-text
pseudoElements.description: The ::target-text CSS pseudo-element represents the text that has been scrolled to if the browser supports scroll-to-text fragments. It allows authors to choose how to highlight that section of text.

pseudoElements.name: ::view-transition
pseudoElements.description: The ::view-transition CSS pseudo-element represents the root of the view transitions overlay, which contains all view transitions and sits over the top of all other page content.

pseudoElements.name: ::view-transition-group
pseudoElements.description: The ::view-transition-group CSS pseudo-element represents a single view transition snapshot group.

pseudoElements.name: ::view-transition-image-pair
pseudoElements.description: The ::view-transition-image-pair CSS pseudo-element represents a container for a view transition's "old" and "new" view states â€” before and after the transition.

pseudoElements.name: ::view-transition-new
pseudoElements.description: The ::view-transition-new CSS pseudo-element represents the "new" view state of a view transition â€” a snapshot live representation of the state after the transition.

pseudoElements.name: ::view-transition-old
pseudoElements.description: The ::view-transition-old CSS pseudo-element represents the "old" view state of a view transition â€” a static snapshot of the old view, before the transition.
